data.name: Authoritative
data.short_desc: Leaders assume personal responsibility for decisions
data.desc: This style is based on the idea that leaders should assume personal responsibility for decisions. The authoritative style is attractive to people who are restless, action-oriented, and have a strong personal vision of what’s needed. While the authoritative leader may sometimes ‘consult’ group members before taking decisions, their favoured approach is to take the decisions first and then ‘tell’ or ‘sell’ them to the rest of the group.
strengths: Group members know exactly where they stand
Decisions can be taken rapidly, which is great in a crisis
Members can concentrate on ‘operational’ tasks, without having to worry about ‘strategic’ issues.
weaknesses: Unlikely to win full commitment from all group members
Can lead to un-informed and shallow decisions.
Can lead to un-informed and shallow decisions.

data.name: Democrative
data.short_desc: Leader is determined to include all group members in decisions
data.desc: The leader is determined to include all group members in decisions about how the group should operate. The democratic style is based on a belief that groups cannot be effective unless all members have an opportunity to participate fully.The democratic leader’s role is largely one of establishing a structure and ground-rules for the group, protecting these, and enabling group activity.
strengths: Gives power to group members
Energises and motivates group members to achieve their tasks
Builds individual responsibility amongst members
weaknesses: May slow down tasks, encouraging talk not action
Can frustrate members who like clear direction
Inappropriate when rapid decisions are needed
The most popular decisions are not always the best

data.name: Facilitative
data.short_desc: Concerned with offering suggestions which group members may or may not take up
data.desc: The facilitative style is concerned with offering suggestions which group members may or may not take up. Structure, content and operation of the group are left to group members to determine.While facilitative leaders may have their own clear opinions about the best courses of action, they are not willing to influence the group unduly with their personal ideas. They believe that group activity should be a constant learning process, and that it is OK to make mistakes so long as people learn from them. The journey is seen as more important than the destination.
strengths: Gives plenty of space for creative ideas to emerge and be explored
Enables individual learning
Can be empowering in the right circumstances
weaknesses: Can allow the group to become aimless and chaotic
The leadership ‘gap’ can get filled by other people, who have to operate as ‘informal’ leaders

data.name: Situational
data.short_desc: The leader attempts to adapt how they behave according to the needs of each situation.
data.desc: Situational leadership is an approach in which the leader attempts to adapt how they behave according to the needs of each situation. The situational leader will vary their style so that it is appropriate for the particular group (for example, their current levels of skill and confidence), and for the particular task in hand.
strengths: Allows groups to change over the time.
adapts to urgent and non-urgent situations.
weaknesses: Difficult to carry off effectively – group members never know what to expect, and may resist changes in style,

data.name: Give in
data.short_desc: I know I’m right and you’re wrong…I’ll just agree with you and move on
data.desc: I know I’m right and you’re wrong…but I don’t know what to do, or it’s too much bother, or who really cares, or you’re too strong, so I’ll just agree with you and move on. This reaction allows resentment to build and can also result in gossiping, bullying and feelings of inadequacy.
strengths: Minimizes injury when we are outmatched; relationships can be maintained
weaknesses: Breeds resentment; exploits the weak

data.name: Run away
data.short_desc: I know I’m right and you’re wrong...o I’m just going to avoid you.
data.desc: I know I’m right and you’re wrong…but you won’t listen to me and I’m intimidated by you so I’m just going to avoid you.This response can lead to passive aggressive behavior, gossiping, subterfuge and sabotage.
strengths: Does not escalate conflict; postpones the inevitable
weaknesses: Unaddressed problems; unresolved problems can become bigger problems in the future

data.name: Team Up
data.short_desc: I know I’m right, but maybe you’re right too…perhaps we can listen to each other
data.desc: I know I’m right, but maybe you’re right too…perhaps we can listen to each other and try to see each other’s perspective; try to walk in each other’s shoes.” This response resolves conflict so both parties are satisfied with the result, and negative feelings are minimized.
strengths: Creates mutual trust; maintains positive relationships; builds commitments
weaknesses: Time consuming; energy consuming

data.name: Pressure
data.short_desc: I know I’m right and you’re wrong...I’m going to convince you
data.desc: I know I’m right and you’re wrong…so I’m going to convince you to come around to my point of view. You’ll thank me for it.This is an authoritarian approach, which – if not kept in check – can easily slip into bullying or harassment
strengths: Goal-oriented; quick
weaknesses: May breed hostility

data.name: Compromise
data.short_desc: I know I’m right and you’re wrong…you’re never going to come around to my point of view
data.desc: I know I’m right and you’re wrong…but you’re never going to come around to my point of view, so why don’t we agree to disagree and I’ll give in a little bit, and you give in a little bit.This response can be useful in complex situations when there is no simple solution; however, it often leaves both parties unsatisfied to a point where resentment can continue to build.
strengths: All parties are equal in power.
weaknesses: Dissatisfaction can breed resentment
